answer_1.text: Jeanne d'Arc, also known as Joan of Arc, was a French peasant girl born around 1412 who claimed to have received visions from saints instructing her to support Charles VII and lead French forces against the English during the Hundred Years' War. She played a crucial role by inspiring and leading the French army to several important victories, most notably the lifting of the siege of Orléans in 1429. Her actions helped pave the way for Charles VII's coronation as king of France. She was captured in 1430, tried for heresy, and executed in 1431, later being canonized as a saint.
